text.div:
ConceptMap_v2-0301_Map (http://hl7.org/fhir/v2-tofhir)

Mapping from http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/v2-0301 to http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/v2-0301

ACTIVE (not intended for production usage). Published on Mar 1, 2020, 12:00:00 AM by HL7 International (HL7 Orders and Observations Workgroup: https://confluence.hl7.org/display/OO/v2-to-FHIR+IG, Keith W. Boone: kboone@ainq.com). Copyright (c) 2020, HL7 International, Inc., All Rights Reserved.

This ConceptMap represents the mapping from the HL7 V2 Table v2-0301 to the FHIR Universal ID Type Value Set.


Source CodeRelationshipDestination CodeComment
DNSis equivalent toDNS
EUI64is equivalent toEUI64
CLIAis equivalent toCLIA
CLIPis equivalent toCLIP
GUIDis equivalent toGUID
HCDis equivalent toHCD
HL7is equivalent toHL7
ISOis equivalent toISO
L,M,Nis equivalent toL,M,N.
Randomis equivalent toRandom
URIis equivalent toURI
UUIDis equivalent toUUID
x400is equivalent tox400
x500is equivalent tox500

name: ConceptMap_v2-0301_Map
description: This ConceptMap represents the mapping from the HL7 V2 Table v2-0301 to the FHIR Universal ID Type Value Set.
copyright: Copyright (c) 2020, HL7 International, Inc., All Rights Reserved.

element.display: An Internet host name, in accordance with RFC 1035; or an IP address. Either in ASCII or as integers, with periods between components (“dotted” notation).

target.display: An Internet host name, in accordance with RFC 1035; or an IP address. Either in ASCII or as integers, with periods between components (“dotted” notation).

element.display: IEEE 64-bit Extended Unique Identifier is comprised of a 24-bit company identifier and a 40-bit instance identifier. The value shall be formatted as 16 ASCII HEX digits, for example, “AABBCC1122334455”. The 24-bit company identifier, formally known as Organizationally Unique Identifier (OUI-24), is guaranteed to be globally unique. The 40-bit extensions are assigned by manufacturers. This identifier is often used in equipment interfaces (e.g., “MAC” address format for IPv4 & IPv6). [See http://standards.ieee.org/regauth/oui/tutorials/EUI64.html for a detailed explanation of the format.]

target.display: IEEE 64-bit Extended Unique Identifier is comprised of a 24-bit company identifier and a 40-bit instance identifier. The value shall be formatted as 16 ASCII HEX digits, for example, “AABBCC1122334455”. The 24-bit company identifier, formally known as Organizationally Unique Identifier (OUI-24), is guaranteed to be globally unique. The 40-bit extensions are assigned by manufacturers. This identifier is often used in equipment interfaces (e.g., “MAC” address format for IPv4 & IPv6). [See http://standards.ieee.org/regauth/oui/tutorials/EUI64.html for a detailed explanation of the format.]

element.display: Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments. Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a “CLIA” assigned number (for labs)

target.display: Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments. Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a “CLIA” assigned number (for labs)

element.display: Clinical laboratory Improvement Program. Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a “CLIP” assigned number (for labs). Used by US Department of Defense.

target.display: Clinical laboratory Improvement Program. Allows for the ability to designate organization identifier as a “CLIP” assigned number (for labs). Used by US Department of Defense.

element.display: The CEN Healthcare Coding Scheme Designator

target.display: The CEN Healthcare Coding Scheme Designator

element.display: An International Standards Organization Object Identifier (OID), in accordance with ISO/IEC 8824. Formatted as decimal digits separated by periods; recommended limit of 64 characters

target.display: An International Standards Organization Object Identifier (OID), in accordance with ISO/IEC 8824. Formatted as decimal digits separated by periods; recommended limit of 64 characters

element.display:
Usually a base64 encoded string of random bits.
 Note: Random IDs are typically used for instance identifiers, rather than an identifier of an Assigning Authority that issues instance identifiers

target.display:
Usually a base64 encoded string of random bits.
 Note: Random IDs are typically used for instance identifiers, rather than an identifier of an Assigning Authority that issues instance identifiers

element.display: The DCE Universal Unique Identifier, in accordance with RFC 4122. Recommended format is 32 hexadecimal digits separated by hyphens, in the digit grouping 8-4-4-4-12

target.display: The DCE Universal Unique Identifier, in accordance with RFC 4122. Recommended format is 32 hexadecimal digits separated by hyphens, in the digit grouping 8-4-4-4-12

element.display: An X.400 MHS identifier. Recommended format is in accordance with RFC 1649

target.display: An X.400 MHS identifier. Recommended format is in accordance with RFC 1649
